titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mathew B. Brady and Levin Corbin Handy Photographic Studios Collection
Brady (Mathew B.) and Handy (Levin Corbin) Photographic Studios Collection
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:12

did.unittitle: Mathew B. Brady and Levin Corbin Handy Photographic Studios Collection

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Photographs, papers, and artifacts created or collected by Mathew B. Brady, Levin Corbin handy, their studios, and their family, 1843-1957. The collection includes images created by Brady during the American Civil War and documents the continual use of these images into the early twentieth century by Handy and his studio. The collection reflects the operations of the Brady and Handy studios in Washington, D.C., from the middle of the nineteenth century through the early twentieth century. It contains work by other photographers and other studios collected by Handy, as well as camera lenses and other photographic artifacts. A small group of papers document aspects of the extended Handy family history.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the William Reese Company on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2006.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Mathew B. Brady and Levin Corbin Handy Photographic Studios Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Mathew B. Brady and Levin Corbin Handy Photographic Studios Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Upon acquisition, the Mathew B. Brady and Levin Corbin Handy Photographic Studios Collection had no discernible order and many items had damage or soiling. A group of flexible photographic negatives were discarded due to severe deterioration.
The processing archivist did not distinguish the rank of military officers and soldiers in the photographic imagery, nor establish individual photographers or dates of images.
In April 2015, library staff revised the finding aid to reflect the storage of photographic material on broken glass carriers, as well as correcting typographical errors.

bioghist.head: Mathew B. Brady (circa 1823-1896)
bioghist.p: Mathew B. Brady (circa 1823-1896) was an American photographer who achieved prominence through his portrait photographs and his organization of photographers to document the American Civil War from his studio in Washington, D.C.

Born in Warren County, New York, to Irish immigrant parents, Brady learned the daguerreotype process in Saratoga, New York. By 1844, he operated a daguerreotype studio in New York, New York. The following year he established his gallery of illustrious Americans, which consisted of daguerreotype portraits of American celebrities, he published a portion as lithographic reproductions in 1850.

In 1849, Brady established a studio in Washington D.C., with the expectation of creating portraits of senators and congressional representatives, but he closed it within a year due to high operating expenses and local competition. While in Washington, he met Juliette Handy, whom he married two years later. Around this time, Brady's eyesight began to fail and he concentrated on the management of his studios, which included posing sitters for their portraits, while employees created the photographs. In 1853, he opened a second studio in New York, New York.

In 1858, Brady re-established a studio in Washington D.C., with Alexander Gardner as his primary photographer. With the onset of the American Civil War, Brady organized a corps of photographers and assistants to document the people, events, and locales of the war. Photographers in this group included George N. Barnard, Alexander Gardner, James Gardner, Timothy H. O'Sullivan, William Pywell, and Thomas C. Roche. The photographers created conventional portraits of individuals and groups, views of military encampments, and the aftermath of battles. Images published or adapted as engravings in publications had the credit "Photograph by Brady."

Brady sought to market images of the American Civil War with little success. During the war, he transferred many original glass plate negatives to the photographic supply firm of E. & H. T. Anthony & Company to settle his debts with the company. In 1942, the Library of Congress purchased much of this material, where it became the Anthony-Taylor-Rand-Ordway-Eaton Collection.

Brady spent an estimated $100,000 to print ten thousand photographic prints documenting the American Civil War, but a lack of customers required him to sell his studios in New York and Washington and declare bankruptcy. In 1875, he finally sold a bulk of his photographs to the United States government for $25,000. Much of this material became part of the files of the Department of War eventually deposited in the United States National Archives and Records Administration. Nevertheless, Brady remained deeply in debt.

By 1883, Brady formed a photographic partnership with his nephew, Levin Corbin Handy, and Samuel C. Chester, to market images from the American Civil War and maintain a photographic studio in Washington. In 1887, Juliette Handy Brady died. Brady continued to face financial difficulties through the remainder of his life. On January 15, 1896, Brady died in the charity ward of Presbyterian Hospital in New York, New York, from complications following a streetcar accident. After his death, his remaining photography files became the property of Levin Corbin Handy.

bioghist.head: Levin Corbin Handy (1855-1932)
bioghist.p: Levin Corbin Handy (1855-1932), an American photographer, was a nephew and former apprentice of Mathew B. Brady.

Born in Washington, D.C., the son of Samuel S. Handy and Mary A. Handy, Handy began working in the Brady studio as an apprentice in 1867. He soon demonstrated himself as a skilled camera operator, and established his own photographic business in Washington by 1871.

Around 1880, Handy entered a photographic partnership with Samuel C. Chester. They operated a studio in Cape May, New Jersey in 1882. By 1883, Handy and Chester partnered with Brady to market images from the American Civil War. Chester ultimately left the partnership, while Handy maintained the studio at his home and studio located at 494 Maryland Avenue Southwest, Washington, D.C. When Mathew B. Brady died in 1896, his remaining photography files became the property of Handy.

In Washington, the L.C. Handy Studio offered an array of traditional photographic services, in particular to the Library of Congress and other governmental agencies. He also provided photograph duplication services to patrons of the Library of Congress and to members of the United States Congress.

Handy died at his home on March 23, 1932. He bequeathed his studio and photographic files, including his collection of Mathew B. Brady, to his daughters, Alice H. Cox and Mary H. Evans. In 1954, the Library of Congress purchased approximately ten thousand original, duplicate, and copy negatives from Cox and Evans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists primarily of photographs created by the studios of Mathew B. Brady and his nephew and former apprentice, Levin Corbin Handy, in Washington, D.C.

The collection includes imagery created by photographers employed by Brady during the American Civil War and documents his marketing of that imagery, as well as the continuing efforts of the Levin C. Handy Studio to promote and market this wartime imagery into the early twentieth century. The collection also documents the functioning of photographic studios in Washington, D.C., from the middle of the nineteenth century to the early twentieth century, and the personal photography and papers of the Handy family. The collection includes the work of other photographers and photographic studios collected by Handy, as well as artifacts related to photography.

This collection largely represents photographic material retained by Handy's daughters. Other photographic materials created by Brady and his studios were transferred to creditors during the American Civil War, purchased by the United States government in 1875, or purchased by Library of Congress in 1954. At the time of processing this collection, many of the images created by the Brady studio were available in digital form from the United States National Archives and Records Administration and the Library of Congress via the Internet.

Each folder in the collection contains a single photographic print, except where two or more photographic prints are noted, and each sleeve contains a single photographic negative, except where two or more film negatives are noted.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Mathew B. Brady Studio. II. Levin Corbin Handy Studio. III. Family Papers and Photographs. IV. Collected Photographs and Artifacts.
Within each series, the photographic materials are arranged according to format and presentation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic prints from the studio of Mathew B. Brady in Washington, D.C. The photographs include studio and exterior portraits of officers serving in the military during the American Civil War; exterior views of battlefields, structures, and military units; and studio portraits of persons in the extended Brady and Handy families. The same image may exist in several subseries.
Many images created by the studio of Mathew B. Brady exist in derivative forms in Series II. Levin Corbin Handy Studio.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Subseries are arranged by relative size of the photographic prints from small to large, with mounted prints preceding unmounted prints in each size. Photographic negatives, arranged by size, are listed following the prints.
Subseries are arranged in the following manner:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Albumen photographic prints created by photographers employed by the studio of Mathew B. Brady mounted on carte-de-visite boards that primarily depict persons in the extended Brady and Handy families, circa 1860-1880.
The series includes two cabinet photographs consisting of a portrait of Adlai Ewing Stevenson and an unidentified girl.
Except where noted, the images are studio portraits. Most have manuscript inscriptions in pencil on their verso.

arrangement.p: Individual card mounts arranged by mount number, which range from 1 to 43, followed by four unnumbered mounts. Photographic prints on each card are expressed in the order they appear on the card from left to right and top to bottom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic prints and negatives, and a small amount of records from the studio of Levin Corbin Handy that include studio portraits and interior and exterior views of structures, buildings, and artwork primarily located in Washington, D.C. Some materials document the sale of images created by the studio of Mathew B. Brady and marketed by the studio of Levin Corbin Handy. The series also includes a small quantity of papers from the studio.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged first with proof books from the studio, followed by photographic prints created by the studio and images originally created by the Mathew B. Brady Studio and printed by the studio, copy photography, oversize photographic prints, then followed by glass and film photographic negatives arranged by size and medium, and then a small amount of papers.
Subseries are arranged in the following manner:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two proof books created by the studio to promote and market its photographs.

did.unittitle: Proof Book of Portraits by the Mathew B. Brady Studio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A disbound stock photograph album of mounted studio portraits reprinted by the studio of Levin Corbin Handy from images originally created by the Mathew B. Brady Studio. Photographic prints that depict individuals are enlarged and cropped from original glass plate negatives for cartes-de-visite to create head and shoulders portraits of the individuals.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Pages from the album are arranged in original order. Each folder contains two leaves (four pages), representing the construction of the album. Each page contains multiple photographic prints, which are described as they appear on the pages from left to right and top to bottom. Some photographic prints are missing, but information about the image number and subject taken from manuscript notes on the leaves is included in the description. The numbers associated with the photographic prints are written on the pages in pencil and ink inscriptions. Some prints are detached from their page. They are placed in the appropriate folder based on identification of the subject.

scopecontent.p: An incomplete bound volume of mounted copy photographs of historical subjects. The boards and first 32 pages of the volume are missing. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographic prints created by the studio from original negatives, including images created by the Mathew B. Brady Studio.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series arranged with prints originally created by the Mathew B. Brady Studio, consisting of portraits followed by photographs of interiors and exteriors, followed by prints and other photographic materials created by the Levin Corbin Handy studio, stereographs, and lantern slides.

did.unittitle: Photographic Prints of Images by the Mathew B. Brady Studio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reprints by the studio of Levin Corbin Handy of images created by the studio of Mathew B. Brady. The photographs primarily depict locations, persons, and events of the American Civil War, as well as some antebellum studio portraits.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by geographical location of the subject, with studio portraits arranged alphabetically by the surname of the subject at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographic prints of interiors, primarily of public buildings in Washington, D.C., and locations outside of the but also including studio portraiture and still lifes, followed by photographic prints of exteriors, primarily of public buildings in Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: First photographic prints of interiors are arranged alphabetically by location, followed by unidentified interior locations and informal portraits, then by still lifes and studio portraiture, and then by exteriors arranged alphabetically by location, followed by unidentified locations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lantern slides of copy photographs of images created by photographers employed by the studio of Mathew B. Brady, that document persons and locations of the American Civil War, followed by images related to World War I, then by images related to excursions by the extended Handy family, then by images of Washington, D.C., and unidentified locations, and then followed by images of lithographs and artwork.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Much of the early correspondence under this heading deals with family financial matters. This includes a letter of indenture of William Henry Bright (the brother of Mary Ann Bright Handy and uncle of Levin Corbin Handy), 1843.

Letters from Robert Handy, serving aboard the United States Revenue Cutters Morris and Howard, to his brother Samuel S. Handy in 1850 include mentions of Brady and his wife living on Staten Island, New York, and the aftermath of the sinking of the bark, Elizabeth, on July 19, 1850.

Letters from Levin Corbin Handy to his then future wife, Emma Sussanna Gessford, include one asking her to attend a prayer meeting in 1874, as well as love poems he wrote to her in 1875 and undated. They were married in 1879.

Single letters of interest to researchers and philographers include an autograph letter signed from Senator Jefferson Davis to Secretary of War John Buchanan Floyd in 1857, and an undated autographed letter signed by Robert Lincoln to Levin Corbin Handy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This heading includes letters between Joseph Gessford and Emma Sussanna Gessford document his service aboard the USS Wyoming, 1879.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily Letters from John W. Johnston, a Second Lieutenant in the 39th Regiment, Ohio Infantry, to his wife, Elizabeth Johnston, and his sister in Medina, Ohio, document his service in the American Civil War during 1862.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence especially documents the family of George M. Kendall (1787-1874), the husband of Elizabeth Bright Kendall (1802-1889), the grandmother of Levin Corbin Handy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters of appointment for William Plume Moran (1810-1897), one of the original clerks for the United States Navy, who served in that role for fifty-three years. Autograph letters signed by a United States Secretary of the Navy, including David Henshaw in 1843, John Young Mason in 1848, and Gideon Welles in 1862.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters from Matilda Steward to her son, Reverend Lanson Steward (born 1824), and his wife, Asby Jane Steward, and an envelope addressed to their son Thomas G. Steward, a chief clerk in the United States Patent Office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographic prints depicting members of the extended Handy family include studio portraits and informal portraits of the children and grandchildren of Levin Corbin Handy. Many of the studio portraits were created by the studios of Mathew B. Brady and Levin Corbin Handy.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Studio portraits are arranged by date followed by locations in Washington, D.C., Pennsylvania, Virginia, and unidentified locations arranged alphabetically by geographic location and then chronologically. Unidentified locations and unidentified individuals are grouped at the end by subject matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographic materials by other photographers and artifacts collected by the studios of Mathew B. Brady and Levin C. Handy and by the family of Levin C. Handy. This series includes various formats of photographic prints and transparencies, as well as artifacts related to the studios and photography.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series arranged first with photographs created by the studio of John J. Jarvis of Washington, D.C., and the stereographs distributed by the firm of Underwood & Underwood of New York, followed by an album compiled by Mary Westerman and photographic materials by other photographers represented and arranged by cased photographs, tintypes, carte-de-viste albums and cartes-de-visite, stereograph cards, cabinet photographs, boudoir cards, and various sizes of prints, followed by mechanical prints, magic lantern slides, ephemera, and oversize materials, and finally artifacts.
Subseries are arranged in the following manner:

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John F. Jarvis (born 1849-died after 1930) was born in England, immigrated to the United States in 1870, and originally served as a photographer in Omaha, Nebraska, before he relocated to Washington, District of Columbia. He operated a studio at 135 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, District of Columbia,

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Underwood & Underwood was an early producer and distributor of stereoscopic and other photographic images, and became a pioneer in the field of news-bureau photography. It was founded in 1882 in Ottawa, Kansas by brothers, Elmer Underwood (1859-1947) and Bert Underwood (1862-1943). They moved their operations to Baltimore, Maryland, and to New York, New York, in 1891. In 1920, the company sold most of its catalog of stereographs to the Keystone View Company.
